ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Hiragana, Katakana, some Kanji. Basic sentence structure. Listening, Speaing, Reading.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very well-organized and structured, although the workload gets harder towards the end (but this was expected). The instructors also promoted a lot of fun, educational activities to bolster learning outside of the classroom, and promoted fellowship opportunities well. It was easy and enjoyable to engage with the course in many ways as a result.
Strength: I learned so much in just one semester and the Yamaguchi is just the best. Weakness: a lot of homework.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The curriculum was well paced, just challenging enough for me to be engaged with it but not so difficult that it discouraged me from trying harder.
Yes, if they're interested in Japanese language and culture and willing to commit to a moderate amount of practice every day.
YES. Try to take L1 with Sensei Yamaguchi if you can. She is the best and makes learning Japanese so much more fun.
